expectations:
- MUST be in Latin American Spanish
      - Should separate nucleophilic addition to carbonyls from enolate chemistry
      - Should break down each named reaction (Aldol, Claisen, Michael) as individual lessons
      - Should cover selectivity control concepts as distinct lessons
      - Should NOT create dedicated lessons teaching SN1/SN2 or elimination reactions (neighboring chapter "Sustitución y eliminación" covers that) — brief contextual references are fine
      - Should NOT create dedicated lessons teaching additions to alkenes or alkynes (neighboring chapter "Adiciones a alquenos y alquinos" covers that) — brief contextual references are fine
      - Should NOT create dedicated lessons teaching aromatic chemistry or electrophilic aromatic substitution (neighboring chapter "Química aromática" covers that) — brief contextual references are fine
      - Should NOT create dedicated lessons teaching general carboxylic acid derivative reactivity or acyl substitution chemistry (neighboring chapter "Ácidos carboxílicos y derivados" covers that) — brief contextual references are fine. IMPORTANT: The Claisen condensation and Dieckmann cyclization ARE explicitly within this chapter's scope (listed in the chapter description as enolate reactions). Do NOT penalize lessons on Claisen/Dieckmann mechanism, enolate-of-ester formation, or related selectivity — these are enolate chemistry, not acyl substitution

      
  - Each lesson should cover a SINGLE, SPECIFIC concept that can be explained within 10 short tweets
  - Break down topics into the smallest, most manageable units possible, so that each lesson can be learned in 2-3 minutes
  - If a topic is too broad, split it into multiple lessons
  - Each lesson should be extremely focused on a SINGLE concept
  - If a lesson is too broad, split it into multiple lessons
  - Each lesson must cover a SINGLE concept. Using "AND", "OR", "VS" (or equivalents in other languages like "e", "ou", "y", "o") in a title is a signal it MAY be too broad — but it is acceptable when the comparison or pairing IS the concept itself (e.g., "DEPT-90 y DEPT-135" where distinguishing two NMR techniques is the lesson, or "IPv4 vs. IPv6 Format" where the format contrast is one concept). Only penalize when AND/OR/VS joins genuinely separate concepts that deserve their own lessons (e.g., "Strings and Lists" where each is a full topic)
  - Lesson titles should be short and specific to the exact concept covered
  - Build a logical progression from basic to advanced concepts
  - Ensure lessons build on knowledge from previous lessons
  - Focus lessons for this specific chapter, not the entire course
  - Don't include summary or review lessons. For example, do NOT create a lesson title "Summary of Key Concepts" or "Review of Chapter"
  - Don't include assessment or quiz lessons
  - Don't include final project or capstone lessons
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words (avoid "learn", "understand", "explore", "introduction to", etc.)
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the lesson content quality
  - Include an extensive list of lessons to fully cover the chapter's scope. The key metric is completeness: are all concepts in the chapter description adequately covered with sufficient granularity? Broad technical chapters (e.g., web fundamentals, Python basics) typically need 80-120+ lessons. Narrower or more specialized chapters (e.g., legal theory of evidence, NMR spectroscopy) may need fewer if the domain is inherently smaller — do not penalize for fewer lessons if the chapter's scope is fully covered

  Neighboring chapter scope judgment:
  - The chapter description is the SOURCE OF TRUTH for what is in-scope. Neighboring chapter constraints are guardrails against scope creep, NOT vetoes over topics listed in the chapter description
  - If a topic is explicitly mentioned in the chapter description, it is in-scope even if it touches on a neighboring chapter's domain (e.g., "Claisen" listed in a carbonyls chapter is in-scope even though esters have their own chapter)
  - The key test: does a lesson teach a topic AS ITS OWN SUBJECT (violation) or through the LENS OF THIS CHAPTER (acceptable)? Documenting empirical patterns/observations of X within this chapter's context is NOT the same as teaching X's theory (e.g., documenting consumption's cyclical behavior is a business cycle fact, not consumption theory)
  - When a lesson's title mentions a neighboring topic, read the description to determine focus. A lesson titled "Cortiços as disease ecologies" focused on disease transmission is health content, not urbanization content

  Things to check:
  - Is each lesson too broad? If so, it should be broken down further
  - Can each concept be explained in 10 short tweets or less? If not, it should be broken down
  - Does each lesson focus on a single specific concept? If not, it should be split
  - Does it have lessons that don't belong in this chapter? If so, they should be removed

rankings.reasoning: Model C provides an extensive, highly granular list of 90 lessons that covers virtually everything in the chapter description with excellent single-concept focus. It systematically breaks down: (1) Carbonyl structure and reactivity (polarization, geometry, electronic effects, steric effects, aldehyde vs ketone reactivity), (2) Nucleophilic addition mechanism (steps, intermediary, protonation, rate-determining step, reversibility), (3) Protection/deprotection of carbonyls, (4) Keto-enol tautomerism and enolization (acid/base catalyzed), (5) Enolate chemistry in great detail (resonance, O vs C coordination, pKa, formation with different bases, kinetic vs thermodynamic, regioselectivity, chelation direction, silyl enol ethers, enamines), (6) O- vs C-alkylation, (7) 1,2 vs 1,4 addition with HSAB rationale, (8) Cuprates, (9) Aldol reaction broken into many focused lessons (product, C-C step, protonation, reversibility, self-aldol, crossed aldol strategies, dehydration, E1cb mechanism, E/Z selectivity), (10) Claisen condensation broken into many steps (product, base choice, enolate formation, tetrahedral intermediate, alkoxide elimination, driving force, workup, crossed Claisen), (11) Dieckmann with ring size considerations, (12) Michael reaction (product, acceptor, donor, C-C step, protonation, reactivity), (13) Robinson annulation broken into connectivity, Michael step, aldol cyclization, dehydration, (14) Selectivity control (chemoselectivity, regioselectivity, stereoselectivity including syn/anti, Zimmerman-Traxler, facial selectivity, chelation control, kinetic vs thermodynamic). The lessons are well-ordered with logical progression. Titles are mostly concise and specific. Some lessons have identical descriptions (lessons 5 and 6 about aldehyde vs ketone reactivity share the same description, which is a flaw). A few titles could be seen as slightly overlapping (e.g., 'Condiciones para control cinético' and 'Condiciones para control termodinámico' alongside 'Control cinético de selectividad' and 'Control termodinámico de selectividad'). It doesn't cover some topics like Wittig, Grignard additions, hydride reductions, hydrates, hemiacetals/acetals, imines, cyanohydrins — these are nucleophilic additions to carbonyls explicitly mentioned in the chapter scope. This is a significant gap. However, it does cover protection as acetal. Actually, looking more carefully, it doesn't cover the specific nucleophilic addition reactions (Grignard, hydrides, water, alcohols, HCN, amines) which are core to 'Adición nucleofílica a carbonilos'. This is a notable omission. It focuses heavily on enolate chemistry and selectivity but misses a large chunk of nucleophilic addition content. Also it doesn't cover halogenation alpha, haloform reaction, or alkylation of enolates explicitly. These are important omissions. Adjusting score down for these gaps.

Model F provides the most extensive list with approximately 160 lessons, showing extreme granularity. It covers: (1) Carbonyl structure in great detail (polarization, resonance, electrophilicity, basicity, LUMO, geometry, Bürgi-Dunitz angle), (2) Nucleophilic addition mechanism (tetrahedral intermediate, proton transfer, activation by acid/Lewis acid/base, reversibility), (3) Aldehyde vs ketone reactivity (steric, inductive, conjugation effects), (4) Specific nucleophilic additions: hydrates (gem-diol with factors), hydrides (NaBH4 with multiple lessons on compatibility/selectivity/ketone reduction, LiAlH4 with quenching), Grignard (with formaldehyde/aldehyde/cetone variants, sensitivity), organolithium, cyanide (pH control, reversibility, chiral center), water/alcohol additions, hemiacetals, imines (carbinolamine, dehydration, pH, hydrolysis), enamines (nucleophilicity, formation, hydrolysis), (5) Alpha chemistry: acidity, enol/enolate structure, resonance, pKa values for different substrates, keto-enol tautomerism, acid/base enolization mechanisms, enol reactivity, (6) Enolate chemistry: O vs C forms, counterion effects (Li, K), aggregation, solvation, bases (LDA, LiHMDS, t-BuOK), kinetic vs thermodynamic enolates with temperature/trapping control, regioselectivity, E/Z geometry, (7) Enamines and silyl enol ethers as enolate equivalents, (8) O- vs C-alkylation with electrophile hardness/softness, (9) Alpha halogenation (mono via enol, poly in base), H/D exchange, (10) Alpha alkylation (concept, electrophile choice, overalkylation, stoichiometric control, dilution), (11) Aldol in extensive detail (C-C bond, base-catalyzed scheme/step/closure, acid-catalyzed scheme/step, products for aldehyde/ketone, E1cb dehydration, driving force, retro-aldol, crossed aldol problems/strategies, intramolecular with ring sizes/dilution), (12) Stereochemistry: Zimmerman-Traxler, Z→syn, E→anti, chelation/non-chelation control, epimerization, (13) Mukaiyama aldol, (14) Claisen in detail (definition, enolate generation, acyl attack, OR departure, driving force, workup, OR matching, Hα requirement, crossed Claisen strategies), (15) Dieckmann (concept, ring sizes), (16) 1,2 vs 1,4 addition (enona, β-carbon electrophilicity, sequences, hard/soft nucleophiles), cuprates, (17) Michael donors (stabilized enolate, enamine), retro-Michael, (18) Chemoselectivity, (19) Selectivity control (base choice, temperature, trapping, metal, crossed aldol strategy, Claisen base matching, 1,2/1,4 control). The coverage is extremely thorough. However, there are significant issues: many lessons are TOO narrow and feel like padding (e.g., separate lessons for 'NaBH4: compatibilidad con solventes próticos', 'NaBH4: quimioselectividad típica', 'NaBH4: reducción de cetonas lenta' — these should be one lesson). The Grignard section has 5+ lessons that are overly fragmented. Some lessons border on trivial ('Trabajo ácido: protonación del alcoholato'). The title format 'X: Y' is used extensively and creates some odd entries. Some lessons slightly venture into territory that could overlap with neighboring chapters (e.g., extensive NaBH4/LiAlH4 details could overlap with general reactivity). Missing Wittig reaction, which is a notable gap for carbonyl chemistry. Missing Robinson annulation, which is explicitly relevant. Missing malonic/acetoacetic ester synthesis. Despite being extensive, some lessons feel artificially split while missing important topics. The sheer volume includes some redundancy (selectivity lessons at the end repeat concepts covered earlier).

Model B provides 73 lessons with excellent coverage and good granularity. Strengths: (1) Thorough coverage of carbonyl structure (structure, aldehyde vs ketone, polarization, orbitals LUMO, relative electrophilicity), (2) Nucleophilic addition mechanism well broken down (general mechanism, tetrahedral intermediate, protonation), (3) Specific additions well covered (hydrates with equilibrium, hemiacetals, acetals as protecting groups, cyanide, Grignard, organolithium, NaBH4, LiAlH4, imines with mechanism and pH control, enamines, Wittig with preparation/mechanism/E-Z selectivity), (4) Keto-enol tautomerism with factors, acid/base catalyzed mechanisms, (5) Enolate chemistry (acidity, ion, resonance, LDA, other bases, kinetic vs thermodynamic with control conditions), (6) Alkylation (enolates, monoalkylation control, malonic synthesis, acetoacetic synthesis, decarboxylation), (7) Aldol in detail (mechanism, product, dehydration, base-catalyzed, acid-catalyzed, crossed with selectivity problems and strategies, intramolecular), (8) Claisen (overview, mechanism, driving force, crossed, Dieckmann with ring size), (9) 1,2 vs 1,4 (conjugated addition, mechanistic difference, factors controlling regioselectivity, Michael reaction with mechanism/donors/acceptors, Robinson annulation with mechanism, cuprates, Grignard vs cuprate), (10) Enamines as enolate equivalents (Stork), (11) HSAB theory, (12) Selectivity control (kinetic vs thermodynamic in enolate reactions, stereoselectivity in aldol, Zimmerman-Traxler, enolate geometry and diastereoselectivity, retrosynthetic disconnections). Very good logical progression. Title 'Aldehídos versus cetonas' uses 'versus' but comparing the two IS the concept, so acceptable. 'Adición 1,2 vs. adición 1,4' similarly acceptable as the comparison is the concept. The last lesson 'Desconexiones retrosintéticas de carbonilos' is somewhat summary-like but teaches a specific skill. 'Control de pH en la formación de iminas y enaminas' uses 'y' but pH control applies to both as one concept. Most titles are concise and focused. Coverage is comprehensive — it includes Wittig (which several others miss), malonic/acetoacetic synthesis, decarboxylation, Stork enamine synthesis, HSAB. Minor issues: 'Condensación aldólica: mecanismo' could be seen as slightly broad. A few lessons could potentially be split further. Missing some selectivity details (e.g., Felkin-Anh model, Mukaiyama aldol). The retrosynthetic lesson at the end borders on summary. Overall very strong.

Model A provides 35 lessons — the shortest list. Coverage is decent but lacks sufficient granularity for an 'extensive' lesson list. Strengths: logical progression, clear single-concept focus per lesson, concise titles and descriptions, covers main topics (carbonyl structure/polarity, nucleophilic addition mechanism, specific additions including hydrates/hemiacetals/acetals/imines/enamines/cyanohydrins/Grignard/NaBH4/LiAlH4/Wittig, keto-enol tautomerism, alpha acidity, enol/enolate formation, LDA, kinetic vs thermodynamic enolato, alpha halogenation, haloform, aldol addition/condensation/crossed/intramolecular, Claisen/Dieckmann, conjugated carbonyls, 1,2 vs 1,4, Michael, Robinson, regioselectivity in conjugated additions, Felkin-Anh). Weaknesses: (1) Only 35 lessons is insufficient for an 'extensive' list — many topics are compressed, (2) Missing alkylation of enolates, (3) Missing malonic/acetoacetic synthesis, (4) Missing decarboxylation, (5) Missing Mukaiyama aldol, (6) Missing HSAB/hard-soft concept, (7) Missing O vs C alkylation, (8) Missing silyl enol ethers, (9) Missing enamines as enolate equivalents (Stork), (10) Missing Claisen crossed, (11) Missing aldol stereochemistry beyond Felkin-Anh (Zimmerman-Traxler is absent), (12) Limited selectivity control coverage. The Felkin-Anh model is included which is good and unique among the models. Overall, good quality per lesson but insufficient breadth and depth for this chapter.

Model E provides 52 lessons with good coverage. Strengths: (1) Covers carbonyl structure and electrophilicity, (2) Nucleophilic additions (HCN, hydrides combined in one lesson, Grignard, water, hemiacetals/acetals combined, imines, enamines, aminative reduction, bisulfite addition), (3) Alpha chemistry (acidity, tautomerism with factors, acid/base catalysis, enolate structure/nucleophilia), (4) Enolate generation and kinetic vs thermodynamic, (5) Alkylation of enolates, (6) Aldol (base-catalyzed, acid-catalyzed, product/dehydration, crossed with selectivity and directed approaches, stereochemistry/Zimmerman-Traxler, intramolecular), (7) Claisen (mechanism, crossed, Dieckmann), (8) Acetoacetic and malonic ester synthesis, (9) Michael (1,4 concept, 1,2 vs 1,4, donors, Robinson with mechanism, β-cetoésters as donors, HSAB, cuprates), (10) Regioselectivity in asymmetric ketones, (11) Silyl enol ethers and Mukaiyama aldol, (12) Decarboxylation, (13) Alpha halogenation (acid and basic/haloform combined), (14) Mannich reaction, (15) Knoevenagel condensation, (16) Stork enamine synthesis. Issues: (1) 'Adición de hidruros al carbonilo' combines NaBH4 and LiAlH4 — should be split, (2) 'Formación de hemiacetales y acetales' combines two concepts with 'y', (3) 'Halogenación alfa en medio básico y reacción del haloformo' combines two concepts with 'y', (4) 'Control de selectividad en reacciones de carbonilos' is too broad/summary-like as the final lesson, (5) 'Reactividad relativa: aldehídos vs. cetonas' uses 'vs.' but the comparison IS the concept so acceptable, (6) 'Enolato cinético vs. termodinámico' similarly acceptable. Some titles use 'introduction'-style phrasing indirectly. Mannich and Knoevenagel are good additions that others miss. Aminación reductiva might be slightly outside scope but is related. Bisulfite addition is a nice detail. The last lesson is summary-like which violates the rules. Overall good but has several combined lessons that should be split, and the breadth while decent could be more granular.

Model D provides 43 lessons. Coverage is reasonable but has gaps and some lessons are too compressed. Strengths: logical progression, covers carbonyl structure/polarity, nucleophilic attack, acid activation, specific additions (hydrates, hemiacetals, acetals, imines, enamines, cyanohydrins, Grignard, organolithium, hydrides combined), alpha chemistry (acidity, enol structure, tautomerism, enolate structure, strong base deprotonation, kinetic/thermodynamic enolatos), alpha halogenation and haloform, alkylation of enolates, aldol (addition, condensation, crossed, intramolecular), Claisen (mechanism, crossed, Dieckmann), conjugated carbonyls, 1,2 vs 1,4, Michael (with donors/acceptors), Robinson, enolate stereochemistry (E/Z), Zimmerman-Traxler, stereochemical control. Issues: (1) 'Adición de hidruros' combines NaBH4 and LiAlH4, (2) Only 43 lessons is somewhat thin for 'extensive', (3) Missing Wittig reaction entirely, (4) Missing malonic/acetoacetic synthesis, (5) Missing decarboxylation, (6) Missing HSAB, (7) Missing silyl enol ethers/Mukaiyama, (8) Missing enamines as enolate equivalents (Stork), (9) Missing O vs C alkylation, (10) Missing selectivity control lessons beyond stereochemistry, (11) Missing cuprate chemistry, (12) 'Carbonilos alfa,beta-insaturados' and 'Electrófilos conjugados' somewhat overlap. Some descriptions are well-written and concise. Title quality is good. Overall decent but insufficient granularity and missing important topics.

Model G provides 49 lessons. Coverage has some notable issues. Strengths: covers carbonyl structure (geometry/polarity, resonance), nucleophilic addition mechanism (reversibility, protonation), hydride donors, organometallics, hemiacetals/acetals, cyanohydrins, imines (with iminium), tautomerism, enol nucleophilicity, enolate generation, kinetic vs thermodynamic, counterion effects, E/Z geometry, O vs C alkylation, resonance in enolates, silyl enol ethers, Mukaiyama aldol, enamines, alkylation, aldol (mechanism, dehydration, intramolecular, crossed aldol selectivity, preformed enolates, Zimmerman-Traxler, retro-aldol, Lewis acid catalysis), Claisen (mechanism, Dieckmann, mixed Claisen, tautomerization), 1,2 vs 1,4, Michael mechanism, HSAB, Robinson, organocatalysis by enamines, regioselectivity, chelation control, pKa. Issues: (1) 'Geometría y polaridad del carbonilo' combines two concepts with 'y' — though they are closely related, (2) 'Donantes de hidruro en adición a carbonilos' is too broad combining NaBH4 and LiAlH4, (3) 'Reacción de organometálicos con carbonilos' combines Grignard and organolithium, (4) 'Hemiacetalización del carbonilo' doesn't separately cover hemiacetals and acetals clearly, (5) 'Tautomería cetona–enol' and 'Nucleofilicidad del enol' are separate which is good, (6) 'Aldol intramolecular y ciclización' title has 'y', (7) 'Aldol intramolecular (Dieckmann en ésteres)' incorrectly conflates aldol intramolecular with Dieckmann — Dieckmann is a Claisen intramolecular, NOT an aldol! This is a factual error, (8) 'Química comparada de aldehídos y cetonas' is somewhat broad/summary-like, (9) Missing Wittig reaction, (10) Missing alpha halogenation and haloform, (11) Missing malonic/acetoacetic synthesis, (12) Missing specific hydrate formation, (13) Missing enamina formation details, (14) 'Catálisis por enaminas en Michael' ventures into organocatalysis which may be beyond scope, (15) Several combined titles violate the splitting rule. The factual error about Dieckmann being an aldol intramolecular is a significant issue (hallucination/inaccuracy). Missing important topics like Wittig and alpha halogenation reduces completeness.

Model F provides an incredibly exceptional output that perfectly follows every instruction in the prompt. It delivers 140 ultra-granular lessons, correctly recognizing the massive scope of carbonyl and enolate chemistry while strictly adhering to the '2-3 minutes / 10 tweets' micro-learning constraint. The titles use a highly effective 'Concept: Subconcept' format that avoids 'AND/OR/VS' joins entirely, and the descriptions are purely factual, concise, and devoid of fluff. The chemistry knowledge is top-tier (e.g., mentioning the Bürgi-Dunitz trajectory, E1cb mechanism, Zimmerman-Traxler models, Mukaiyama aldol, etc.) without ever bleeding into out-of-scope neighboring chapter domains.

Model C is outstanding, producing 96 highly granular lessons that break down the chapter beautifully. It successfully isolates single concepts (e.g., separating 'Aldehídos: mayor reactividad relativa' and 'Cetonas: menor reactividad relativa') and follows the negative constraints regarding fluff and 'AND/OR' operators. The only minor critique is that some descriptions use a slightly meta, question-like framing ('Cómo se...', 'Qué define...') rather than the purely factual statement style shown in the prompt's examples, but it remains an excellent instructional design.

Model B delivers a very good, extensive list of 69 lessons. It correctly splits hemiacetal and acetal formation, breaks down mechanisms logically, and maintains a high level of accuracy. It uses 'versus' in a few titles (e.g., 'Aldehídos versus cetonas', 'Adición 1,2 vs. adición 1,4'), which is acceptable under the prompt's exception for when the comparison itself is the concept. However, it groups a few concepts slightly more broadly than Models F and C.

Model D provides a very solid list of 43 lessons with strictly factual descriptions and zero 'y/o' violations. It captures advanced granularity in some areas (like separating E and Z enolate stereochemistry). However, given the vast scope of this specific chemistry chapter, 43 lessons are not extensive enough to cover all the nuances at a micro-learning level compared to the higher-ranked models.

Model A cleanly follows the formatting and negative constraints, providing a well-structured progression with concise descriptions and no 'y/o/vs' violations. However, with only 36 lessons, it fails to achieve the 'extensive' and 'micro-granular' depth expected for such a massive technical topic. It covers the material well, but the lessons are inherently broader than the 2-3 minute scope requested.

Model E suffers a significant penalty for violating the critical negative constraint regarding 'AND/OR/VS' operators joining distinct concepts. Titles like 'Formación de hemiacetales y acetales' (which the prompt's examples explicitly show should be separated) and 'Halogenación alfa en medio básico y reacción del haloformo' combine multiple steps and concepts into single lessons, defeating the micro-learning goal.

Model G receives a heavy penalty for repeated violations of the single-concept rule and the 'AND/OR/VS' constraint. Titles such as 'Geometría y polaridad del carbonilo', 'Resonancia y carga parcial en carbonilos', and 'Aldol intramolecular y ciclización' join genuinely separate concepts. Furthermore, the descriptions are broad and summarize multiple steps, directly contradicting the micro-learning granularity requested.

Muy buena granularidad (muchas micro-lecciones realmente de un solo concepto), progreso lógico, y cobertura amplia de: adición nucleofílica a carbonilos, enol/enolatos, aldol, Claisen/Dieckmann, Michael/Robinson y múltiples ejes de selectividad (quimio-, regio-, estereo-, control cinético/termodinámico, selección de cara). Evita meterse en SN1/SN2 como tema propio. Pequeñas oportunidades: falta de algunas adiciones “clásicas” específicas (p.ej., Wittig, hidratación explícita, cianohidrinas) y algunas piezas podrían ser redundantes, pero globalmente es el conjunto más alineado con ‘extenso + micro’ y con control de selectividad como lecciones separadas.

Extremadamente granular y extenso; separa bien adición a carbonilos vs química de enolatos; cubre en profundidad control de selectividad (HSAB, metal/solvente, O vs C, cinético/termodinámico, E/Z del enolato, aldol cruzada dirigida, etc.) y descompone mecanismos en pasos. Muy fuerte para el criterio “10 tweets”. Debilidades: no incluye explícitamente Claisen/Dieckmann como reacciones nombradas (sí aparece mucho de Michael/aldol y conceptos de Claisen de forma parcial, pero falta la lección explícita y completa), y no trata Wittig; también hay algo de sobre-hipergranularidad/solapamiento. Aun así, calidad alta.

Cobertura muy completa y bien organizada: adición nucleofílica (muchos nucleófilos), enolización/enolatos, aldol (base/ácido, cruzada, intramolecular), Claisen/Dieckmann (mecanismo, fuerza impulsora, cruzada), Michael (donador/aceptor, mecanismo), Robinson; además incluye varios módulos de selectividad (E/Z en Wittig, cinético/termodinámico, Zimmerman–Traxler, geometría del enolato). Puntos en contra: varias lecciones siguen siendo algo “macro” (p.ej., “Teoría HSAB…”, “Desconexiones retrosintéticas…”) y algunas mezclan más de un concepto; también usa “versus” en algunos títulos aunque el concepto comparativo lo justifica. En general, muy sólido.

Buena cobertura global e incluye reacciones adicionales útiles (Mannich, Knoevenagel, Mukaiyama, Stork), además de selectividad. Sin embargo, varias lecciones son demasiado amplias para 2–3 minutos (p.ej., “Control de selectividad en reacciones de carbonilos” es claramente multi-concepto), y varios títulos incluyen “y” uniendo conceptos que deberían separarse (“Formación de hemiacetales y acetales”, “Halogenación alfa… y reacción del haloformo”). También roza el tema de SN2 en el título/descripción de alquilación de enolatos; es contextual, pero se vuelve un mini-tema. Granularidad y cumplimiento de reglas de títulos peor que B/C/F.

Lista razonablemente enfocada, con separación básica entre adición a carbonilos y química de enoles/enolatos, e incluye Aldol/Claisen/Michael/Robinson y algo de selectividad (Felkin–Anh, regioselectividad en conjugadas). Problemas: no es lo bastante extensa para el alcance del capítulo; faltan muchas lecciones de control de selectividad (O vs C, control cinético/termodinámico más operacional, selectividad en aldol/Claisen/Michael), y no descompone mecanismos/variantes clave. Además incluye Wittig (válido) pero omite bastantes piezas comunes (pH en iminas, organolitios, etc.).

Cobertura básica de los bloques principales, pero es poco extensa y a menudo demasiado general para el estándar “extenso” del prompt. Faltan muchos elementos de control de selectividad y desgloses mecanísticos (p.ej., condiciones ácido/base en aldol y enolización, diferencias 1,2/1,4 con criterios, fuerza impulsora en Claisen, estrategias de selectividad en cruzadas). También agrupa conceptos en algunas entradas (p.ej., “Adición de hidruros” sin separar NaBH4 vs LiAlH4) y no cubre varias reacciones/nucleófilos típicos. Cumple mínimamente, pero lejos de lo requerido.

Cubre muchos temas relevantes (carbonilos, enolatos, aldol, Claisen, Michael, Robinson, Mukaiyama), pero presenta varios incumplimientos importantes de granularidad y de exactitud/claridad. Ejemplo crítico: título “Aldol intramolecular (Dieckmann en ésteres)” mezcla/ confunde aldol intramolecular con Dieckmann (Claisen intramolecular), lo que es conceptualmente incorrecto. También hay bastantes lecciones demasiado amplias (muchos “mecanismo + condiciones + selectividad” en una sola). Incluye algo de contenido más allá del foco micro y con títulos en inglés (“Robinson annulation”). Por las imprecisiones, cae al final.
